chaptersContent.content: By the waters of Babylon, there we sat down and wept, when we remembered Zion. How shall we sing the Lord's song in a foreign land? If I forget you, O Jerusalem, let my right hand forget its skill!

chaptersContent.title: I Give You Thanks, O Lord
chaptersContent.summary: Thanksgiving for God's faithfulness and answered prayer
chaptersContent.content: I give you thanks, O Lord, with my whole heart; before the gods I sing your praise; I bow down toward your holy temple and give thanks to your name for your steadfast love and your faithfulness.

chaptersContent.title: O Lord, You Have Searched Me
chaptersContent.summary: God's omniscience and intimate knowledge of us
chaptersContent.content: O Lord, you have searched me and known me! You know when I sit down and when I rise up; you discern my thoughts from afar. I praise you, for I am fearfully and wonderfully made. Wonderful are your works; my soul knows it very well.

chaptersContent.title: Deliver Me, O Lord, from Evil Men
chaptersContent.summary: Prayer for protection from violent and wicked people
chaptersContent.content: Deliver me, O Lord, from evil men; preserve me from violent men, who plan evil things in their heart and stir up wars continually. I know that the Lord will maintain the cause of the afflicted.

chaptersContent.title: O Lord, I Call Upon You
chaptersContent.summary: Prayer for protection and guidance in speech
chaptersContent.content: O Lord, I call upon you; hasten to me! Give ear to my voice when I call to you! Set a guard, O Lord, over my mouth; keep watch over the door of my lips!

chaptersContent.title: With My Voice I Cry Out
chaptersContent.summary: Prayer for deliverance when no refuge is found
chaptersContent.content: With my voice I cry out to the Lord; with my voice I plead for mercy to the Lord. I pour out my complaint before him; I tell my trouble before him. Bring me out of prison, that I may give thanks to your name!

chaptersContent.title: Hear My Prayer, O Lord
chaptersContent.summary: Prayer for mercy and guidance in distress
chaptersContent.content: Hear my prayer, O Lord; give ear to my pleas for mercy! In your faithfulness answer me, in your righteousness! Let me hear in the morning of your steadfast love, for in you I trust.

chaptersContent.title: Blessed Be the Lord, My Rock
chaptersContent.summary: Praise for God's deliverance and prayer for blessing
chaptersContent.content: Blessed be the Lord, my rock, who trains my hands for war, and my fingers for battle; my steadfast love and my fortress, my stronghold and my deliverer, my shield and he in whom I take refuge.

chaptersContent.title: Great Is the Lord
chaptersContent.summary: Praise for God's greatness and His care for all
chaptersContent.content: I will extol you, my God and King, and bless your name forever and ever. The Lord is gracious and merciful, slow to anger and abounding in steadfast love. The Lord is near to all who call on him in truth.

chaptersContent.title: Put Not Your Trust in Princes
chaptersContent.summary: Praise for God's help and warning against trusting men
chaptersContent.content: Praise the Lord! Praise the Lord, O my soul! Put not your trust in princes, in a son of man, in whom there is no salvation. The Lord sets the prisoners free; the Lord opens the eyes of the blind.

chaptersContent.title: Praise the Lord! For It Is Good
chaptersContent.summary: Praise for God's care for Jerusalem and His creation
chaptersContent.content: Praise the Lord! For it is good to sing praises to our God; for it is pleasant, and a song of praise is fitting. The Lord builds up Jerusalem; he gathers the outcasts of Israel.

chaptersContent.title: Praise the Lord from the Heavens
chaptersContent.summary: Call for all creation to praise the Lord
chaptersContent.content: Praise the Lord! Praise the Lord from the heavens; praise him in the heights! Let them praise the name of the Lord, for he commanded and they were created. Let them praise the name of the Lord, for his name alone is exalted.

chaptersContent.title: Sing to the Lord a New Song
chaptersContent.summary: Call to praise God with dance and song
chaptersContent.content: Praise the Lord! Sing to the Lord a new song, his praise in the assembly of the godly! Let them praise his name with dancing, making melody to him with tambourine and lyre!

chaptersContent.title: Let Everything Praise the Lord
chaptersContent.summary: Final doxology calling all to praise God with instruments
chaptersContent.content: Praise the Lord! Praise God in his sanctuary; praise him in his mighty heavens! Praise him for his mighty deeds; praise him according to his excellent greatness! Let everything that has breath praise the Lord!

books.name: Proverbs
books.description: Wisdom literature providing practical guidance for righteous living
books.author: Solomon and others

chaptersContent.title: The Purpose of Proverbs
chaptersContent.summary: Introduction to the purpose and value of wisdom and instruction
chaptersContent.content: The fear of the Lord is the beginning of knowledge; fools despise wisdom and instruction. To receive instruction in wise dealing, in righteousness, justice, and equity.

chaptersContent.title: Trust in the Lord
chaptersContent.summary: Wisdom about trusting God and the benefits of following His ways
chaptersContent.content: Trust in the Lord with all your heart, and do not lean on your own understanding. In all your ways acknowledge him, and he will make straight your paths.

chaptersContent.title: The Value of Wisdom
chaptersContent.summary: The benefits of seeking wisdom and understanding
chaptersContent.content: If you seek it like silver and search for it as for hidden treasures, then you will understand the fear of the Lord and find the knowledge of God. For the Lord gives wisdom; from his mouth come knowledge and understanding.

chaptersContent.title: Get Wisdom
chaptersContent.summary: Father's instruction to get wisdom and avoid evil
chaptersContent.content: The beginning of wisdom is this: Get wisdom, and whatever you get, get insight. Keep hold of instruction; do not let go; guard her, for she is your life. Keep your heart with all vigilance, for from it flow the springs of life.

chaptersContent.title: Warning Against Adultery
chaptersContent.summary: Warning about the dangers of sexual immorality
chaptersContent.content: For the lips of a forbidden woman drip honey, and her speech is smoother than oil, but in the end she is bitter as wormwood, sharp as a two-edged sword. Drink water from your own cistern, flowing water from your own well.

chaptersContent.title: Practical Warnings
chaptersContent.summary: Warnings about laziness, adultery, and other sins
chaptersContent.content: Go to the ant, O sluggard; consider her ways, and be wise. There are six things that the Lord hates, seven that are an abomination to him: haughty eyes, a lying tongue, and hands that shed innocent blood.

chaptersContent.title: The Wiles of the Adulteress
chaptersContent.summary: Warning about the seductive ways of the immoral woman
chaptersContent.content: Keep my commandments and live; keep my teaching as the apple of your eye; bind them on your fingers; write them on the tablet of your heart. With much seductive speech she persuades him; with her smooth talk she compels him.

chaptersContent.title: The Blessings of Wisdom
chaptersContent.summary: Wisdom personified speaking of her value and benefits
chaptersContent.content: For wisdom is better than jewels, and all that you may desire cannot compare with her. I love those who love me, and those who seek me diligently find me. For whoever finds me finds life and obtains favor from the Lord.

chaptersContent.title: Wisdom and Folly
chaptersContent.summary: Contrast between wisdom's invitation and folly's call
chaptersContent.content: The fear of the Lord is the beginning of wisdom, and the knowledge of the Holy One is insight. The woman Folly is loud; she is seductive and knows nothing. But he does not know that the dead are there, that her guests are in the depths of Sheol.

chaptersContent.title: The Proverbs of Solomon
chaptersContent.summary: Collection of wise sayings about righteous and wicked living
chaptersContent.content: The proverbs of Solomon. A wise son makes a glad father, but a foolish son is a sorrow to his mother. The memory of the righteous is a blessing, but the name of the wicked will rot. The blessing of the Lord makes rich, and he adds no sorrow with it.

chaptersContent.title: Righteousness and Wickedness
chaptersContent.summary: Contrast between the outcomes of righteous and wicked living
chaptersContent.content: When pride comes, then comes disgrace, but with the humble is wisdom. Where there is no guidance, a people falls, but in an abundance of counselors there is safety. Whoever brings blessing will be enriched, and one who waters will himself be watered.

chaptersContent.title: Words and Deeds
chaptersContent.summary: Wisdom about speech, work, and character
chaptersContent.content: Whoever loves discipline loves knowledge, but he who hates reproof is stupid. The way of a fool is right in his own eyes, but a wise man listens to advice. Lying lips are an abomination to the Lord, but those who act faithfully are his delight.

chaptersContent.title: Discipline and Instruction
chaptersContent.summary: Wisdom about discipline, wealth, and relationships
chaptersContent.content: A wise son hears his father's instruction, but a scoffer does not listen to rebuke. Whoever walks with the wise becomes wise, but the companion of fools will suffer harm. Whoever spares the rod hates his son, but he who loves him is diligent to discipline him.

chaptersContent.title: The Fear of the Lord
chaptersContent.summary: Wisdom about fearing God and living wisely
chaptersContent.content: The wisest of women builds her house, but folly with her own hands tears it down. There is a way that seems right to a man, but its end is the way to death. The fear of the Lord is a fountain of life, that one may turn away from the snares of death.

chaptersContent.title: A Soft Answer
chaptersContent.summary: Wisdom about speech, attitude, and God's oversight
chaptersContent.content: A soft answer turns away wrath, but a harsh word stirs up anger. The eyes of the Lord are in every place, keeping watch on the evil and the good. The fear of the Lord is instruction in wisdom, and humility comes before honor.

chaptersContent.title: The Lord's Sovereignty
chaptersContent.summary: Wisdom about God's control and human responsibility
chaptersContent.content: The plans of the heart belong to man, but the answer of the tongue is from the Lord. Commit your work to the Lord, and your plans will be established. The heart of man plans his way, but the Lord establishes his steps.

chaptersContent.title: Family and Friends
chaptersContent.summary: Wisdom about relationships, speech, and character
chaptersContent.content: Better is a dry morsel with quiet than a house full of feasting with strife. A friend loves at all times, and a brother is born for adversity. A joyful heart is good medicine, but a crushed spirit dries up the bones.

chaptersContent.title: The Power of Words
chaptersContent.summary: Wisdom about speech, pride, and relationships
chaptersContent.content: Whoever isolates himself seeks his own desire; he breaks out against all sound judgment. The name of the Lord is a strong tower; the righteous man runs into it and is safe. Death and life are in the power of the tongue, and those who love it will eat its fruits.

chaptersContent.title: Wealth and Character
chaptersContent.summary: Wisdom about wealth, character, and relationships
chaptersContent.content: Better is a poor person who walks in his integrity than one who is crooked in speech and is a fool. Whoever is generous to the poor lends to the Lord, and he will repay him for his deed. The fear of the Lord leads to life, and whoever has it rests content.

chaptersContent.title: Wine and Wisdom
chaptersContent.summary: Wisdom about alcohol, business, and character
chaptersContent.content: Wine is a mocker, strong drink a brawler, and whoever is led astray by it is not wise. The righteous who walks in his integrityblessed are his children after him! A man's steps are from the Lord; how then can man understand his way?

chaptersContent.title: The Lord's Sovereignty
chaptersContent.summary: Wisdom about God's control and human behavior
chaptersContent.content: The king's heart is a stream of water in the hand of the Lord; he turns it wherever he will. To do righteousness and justice is more acceptable to the Lord than sacrifice. Whoever pursues righteousness and kindness will find life, righteousness, and honor.

chaptersContent.title: Training Children
chaptersContent.summary: Wisdom about child-rearing and character development
chaptersContent.content: A good name is to be chosen rather than great riches, and favor is better than silver or gold. Train up a child in the way he should go; even when he is old he will not depart from it. Folly is bound up in the heart of a child, but the rod of discipline drives it far from him.

chaptersContent.title: Warnings and Instructions
chaptersContent.summary: Warnings about gluttony, drunkenness, and other sins
chaptersContent.content: Do not toil to acquire wealth; be discerning enough to desist. Let not your heart envy sinners, but continue in the fear of the Lord all the day. My son, give me your heart, and let your eyes observe my ways.

chaptersContent.title: More Sayings of the Wise
chaptersContent.summary: Additional wisdom about justice, planning, and character
chaptersContent.content: By wisdom a house is built, and by understanding it is established; by knowledge the rooms are filled with all precious and pleasant riches. For the righteous falls seven times and rises again, but the wicked stumble in times of calamity.

chaptersContent.title: More Proverbs of Solomon
chaptersContent.summary: Additional proverbs collected by Hezekiah's men
chaptersContent.content: It is the glory of God to conceal things, but the glory of kings is to search things out. If your enemy is hungry, give him bread to eat, and if he is thirsty, give him water to drink. A man without self-control is like a city broken into and left without walls.

chaptersContent.title: Fools and Sluggards
chaptersContent.summary: Wisdom about fools, sluggards, and their characteristics
chaptersContent.content: Like snow in summer or rain in harvest, so honor is not fitting for a fool. Like a dog that returns to his vomit is a fool who repeats his folly. For lack of wood the fire goes out, and where there is no whisperer, quarreling ceases.

chaptersContent.title: Friendship and Planning
chaptersContent.summary: Wisdom about relationships, planning, and character
chaptersContent.content: Do not boast about tomorrow, for you do not know what a day may bring. Iron sharpens iron, and one man sharpens another. Know well the condition of your flocks, and give attention to your herds.

chaptersContent.title: Righteousness and Wickedness
chaptersContent.summary: Contrast between righteous and wicked living
chaptersContent.content: The wicked flee when no one pursues, but the righteous are bold as a lion. Whoever conceals his transgressions will not prosper, but he who confesses and forsakes them will obtain mercy. Whoever trusts in his own mind is a fool, but he who walks in wisdom will be delivered.

chaptersContent.title: Leadership and Discipline
chaptersContent.summary: Wisdom about leadership, discipline, and character
chaptersContent.content: He who is often reproved, yet stiffens his neck, will suddenly be broken beyond healing. The rod and reproof give wisdom, but a child left to himself brings shame to his mother. The fear of man lays a snare, but whoever trusts in the Lord is safe.

chaptersContent.title: The Words of Agur
chaptersContent.summary: Agur's wisdom about God's greatness and human limitations
chaptersContent.content: Every word of God proves true; he is a shield to those who take refuge in him. Remove far from me falsehood and lying; give me neither poverty nor riches; feed me with the food that is needful for me.

chaptersContent.title: The Virtuous Woman
chaptersContent.summary: Description of a woman of noble character and her qualities
chaptersContent.content: An excellent wife who can find? She is far more precious than jewels. The heart of her husband trusts in her, and he will have no lack of gain.

books.name: Ecclesiastes
books.description: Solomon's reflections on the meaning and purpose of life
books.author: Solomon

chaptersContent.title: Everything is Vanity
chaptersContent.summary: The Preacher introduces the theme that all earthly pursuits are vanity
chaptersContent.content: Vanity of vanities, says the Preacher, vanity of vanities! All is vanity. What has been is what will be, and what has been done is what will be done, and there is nothing new under the sun. I have seen everything that is done under the sun, and behold, all is vanity and a striving after wind.

chaptersContent.title: The Vanity of Pleasure and Wisdom
chaptersContent.summary: Solomon tests pleasure, wisdom, and work but finds them all vanity
chaptersContent.content: Then I considered all that my hands had done and the toil I had expended in doing it, and behold, all was vanity and a striving after wind, and there was nothing to be gained under the sun. Then I saw that there is more gain in wisdom than in folly, as there is more gain in light than in darkness. There is nothing better for a person than that he should eat and drink and find enjoyment in his toil. This also, I saw, is from the hand of God.

chaptersContent.title: A Time for Everything
chaptersContent.summary: Famous passage about times and seasons in life
chaptersContent.content: For everything there is a season, and a time for every matter under heaven: a time to be born, and a time to die; a time to plant, and a time to pluck up what is planted.

chaptersContent.title: The Vanity of Toil
chaptersContent.summary: Observations about oppression, envy, and the value of companionship
chaptersContent.content: Two are better than one, because they have a good reward for their toil. And though a man might prevail against one who is alone, two will withstand hima threefold cord is not quickly broken. Better is a handful of quietness than two hands full of toil and a striving after wind.

chaptersContent.title: The Vanity of Wealth
chaptersContent.summary: Warnings about hasty vows and the futility of wealth
chaptersContent.content: Be not rash with your mouth, nor let your heart be hasty to utter a word before God, for God is in heaven and you are on earth. Therefore let your words be few. He who loves money will not be satisfied with money, nor he who loves wealth with his income; this also is vanity. As he came from his mother's womb he shall go again, naked as he came, and shall take nothing for his toil that he may carry away in his hand.

chaptersContent.title: The Vanity of Life
chaptersContent.summary: Observations about the futility of human toil and the value of contentment
chaptersContent.content: There is an evil that I have seen under the sun, and it lies heavy on mankind: a man to whom God gives wealth, possessions, and honor, so that he lacks nothing of all that he desires, yet God does not give him power to enjoy them, but a stranger enjoys them. This is vanity; it is a grievous evil. Better is the sight of the eyes than the wandering of the appetite: this also is vanity and a striving after wind.

chaptersContent.title: Wisdom and Folly
chaptersContent.summary: The value of wisdom over folly and the importance of considering the end
chaptersContent.content: A good name is better than precious ointment, and the day of death than the day of birth. It is better to go to the house of mourning than to go to the house of feasting, for this is the end of all mankind, and the living will lay it to heart. The end of a thing is better than its beginning, and the patient in spirit is better than the proud in spirit.

chaptersContent.title: The Limits of Human Wisdom
chaptersContent.summary: The difficulty of understanding God's ways and the importance of fearing Him
chaptersContent.content: Who is like the wise? And who knows the interpretation of a thing? A man's wisdom makes his face shine, and the hardness of his face is changed. Whoever keeps a command will experience no harm, and the wise heart will know the proper time and the just way. Though a sinner does evil a hundred times and prolongs his life, yet I know that it will be well with those who fear God, because they fear before him.

chaptersContent.title: Death and Life
chaptersContent.summary: The certainty of death and the value of enjoying life while we can
chaptersContent.content: But all this I laid to heart, examining it all, how the righteous and the wise and their deeds are in the hand of God. Whether it is love or hate, man does not know; both are before him. But he who is joined with all the living has hope, for a living dog is better than a dead lion. Whatever your hand finds to do, do it with your might, for there is no work or thought or knowledge or wisdom in Sheol, to which you are going.

chaptersContent.title: Wisdom and Folly in Daily Life
chaptersContent.summary: Practical wisdom for daily living and avoiding foolishness
chaptersContent.content: Dead flies make the perfumer's ointment give off a stench; so a little folly outweighs wisdom and honor. If the anger of the ruler rises against you, do not leave your place, for calmness will lay great offenses to rest. Through sloth the roof sinks in, and through indolence the house leaks.

chaptersContent.title: Investing in Life
chaptersContent.summary: Encouragement to be generous and enjoy life while preparing for the future
chaptersContent.content: Cast your bread upon the waters, for you will find it after many days. Give a portion to seven, or even to eight, for you know not what disaster may happen on earth. In the morning sow your seed, and at evening withhold not your hand, for you do not know which will prosper, this or that, or whether both alike will be good. Rejoice, O young man, in your youth, and let your heart cheer you in the days of your youth.

chaptersContent.title: Remember Your Creator
chaptersContent.summary: The conclusion: fear God and keep His commandments
chaptersContent.content: Remember also your Creator in the days of your youth, before the evil days come and the years draw near of which you will say, 'I have no pleasure in them.'

books.name: Song of Solomon
books.description: Poetic celebration of love between husband and wife
books.author: Solomon

chaptersContent.title: The Beginning of Love
chaptersContent.summary: The bride expresses her love and desire for the bridegroom
chaptersContent.content: Let him kiss me with the kisses of his mouth! For your love is better than wine. Draw me after you; let us run. The king has brought me into his chambers. Behold, you are beautiful, my love; behold, you are beautiful; your eyes are doves.

chaptersContent.title: The Beloved's Beauty
chaptersContent.summary: The lover and beloved express their love for each other
chaptersContent.content: My beloved speaks and says to me: 'Arise, my love, my beautiful one, and come away, for behold, the winter is past, the rain is over and gone. My beloved is mine, and I am his; he grazes among the lilies.'

chaptersContent.title: Seeking and Finding
chaptersContent.summary: The bride seeks her beloved and describes their wedding procession
chaptersContent.content: On my bed by night I sought him whom my soul loves; I sought him, but found him not. I found him whom my soul loves. I held him, and would not let him go. Go out, O daughters of Zion, and look upon King Solomon, with the crown with which his mother crowned him on the day of his wedding, on the day of the gladness of his heart.

chaptersContent.title: The Beauty of Love
chaptersContent.summary: The bridegroom praises the beauty of his bride
chaptersContent.content: Behold, you are beautiful, my love, behold, you are beautiful! Your eyes are doves behind your veil. You are altogether beautiful, my love; there is no flaw in you. Awake, O north wind, and come, O south wind! Blow upon my garden, let its spices flow.

chaptersContent.title: Love's Challenges
chaptersContent.summary: The bride misses an opportunity but continues to praise her beloved
chaptersContent.content: I slept, but my heart was awake. A voice! My beloved is knocking. My beloved is radiant and ruddy, distinguished among ten thousand. His mouth is most sweet, and he is altogether desirable. This is my beloved and this is my friend, O daughters of Jerusalem.

chaptersContent.title: Mutual Admiration
chaptersContent.summary: The lovers express mutual admiration and exclusive devotion
chaptersContent.content: I am my beloved's and my beloved is mine; he grazes among the lilies. My dove, my perfect one, is the only one, the only one of her mother, the favorite of the one who bore her. Return, return, O Shulammite, return, return, that we may look upon you.

chaptersContent.title: The Dance of Love
chaptersContent.summary: Celebration of physical love and beauty in marriage
chaptersContent.content: How beautiful and pleasant you are, O loved one, with all your delights! I am my beloved's, and his desire is for me. Come, my beloved, let us go out into the fields and lodge in the villages; there I will give you my love.

chaptersContent.title: Love is Strong
chaptersContent.summary: The strength and value of true love
chaptersContent.content: Set me as a seal upon your heart, as a seal upon your arm, for love is strong as death, jealousy is fierce as the grave. Its flashes are flashes of fire, the very flame of the Lord. Many waters cannot quench love, neither can floods drown it.

books.name: Isaiah
books.description: Prophecies of judgment and salvation, including Messianic prophecies
books.author: Isaiah

chaptersContent.title: The Vision of Isaiah
chaptersContent.summary: Isaiah's call to prophecy and God's indictment of Judah
chaptersContent.content: The vision of Isaiah the son of Amoz, which he saw concerning Judah and Jerusalem in the days of Uzziah, Jotham, Ahaz, and Hezekiah, kings of Judah. Come now, let us reason together, says the Lord: though your sins are like scarlet, they shall be as white as snow.

chaptersContent.title: The Mountain of the Lord
chaptersContent.summary: Prophecy of the Lord's house established and judgment on the proud
chaptersContent.content: It shall come to pass in the latter days that the mountain of the house of the Lord shall be established as the highest of the mountains, and shall be lifted up above the hills; and all the nations shall flow to it. And many peoples shall come, and say: 'Come, let us go up to the mountain of the Lord.'

chaptersContent.title: Judgment on Judah and Jerusalem
chaptersContent.summary: God's judgment on the leaders and people of Judah
chaptersContent.content: For behold, the Lord God of hosts is taking away from Jerusalem and from Judah support and supply, all support of bread, and all support of water. For Jerusalem has stumbled, and Judah has fallen, because their speech and their deeds are against the Lord.

chaptersContent.title: The Branch of the Lord
chaptersContent.summary: Promise of the Branch and restoration of Zion
chaptersContent.content: In that day the branch of the Lord shall be beautiful and glorious, and the fruit of the land shall be the pride and honor of the survivors of Israel. And he who is left in Zion and remains in Jerusalem will be called holy, everyone who has been recorded for life in Jerusalem.

chaptersContent.title: The Song of the Vineyard
chaptersContent.summary: Parable of the vineyard and woes against the wicked
chaptersContent.content: Let me sing for my beloved my love song concerning his vineyard: My beloved had a vineyard on a very fertile hill. For the vineyard of the Lord of hosts is the house of Israel, and the men of Judah are his pleasant planting; and he looked for justice, but behold, bloodshed.

chaptersContent.title: Isaiah's Commission
chaptersContent.summary: Isaiah sees the Lord and receives his prophetic commission
chaptersContent.content: In the year that King Uzziah died I saw the Lord sitting upon a throne, high and lifted up; and the train of his robe filled the temple. And one called to another and said: 'Holy, holy, holy is the Lord of hosts; the whole earth is full of his glory!'

chaptersContent.title: The Sign of Immanuel
chaptersContent.summary: Prophecy of the virgin birth and Immanuel
chaptersContent.content: Therefore the Lord himself will give you a sign. Behold, the virgin shall conceive and bear a son, and shall call his name Immanuel.

chaptersContent.title: The Coming Assyrian Invasion
chaptersContent.summary: Isaiah warns of Assyrian invasion and calls for trust in God
chaptersContent.content: Take counsel together, but it will come to nothing; speak a word, but it will not stand, for God is with us. But the Lord of hosts, him you shall honor as holy. Let him be your fear, and let him be your dread.

chaptersContent.title: The Prince of Peace
chaptersContent.summary: Prophecy of the Messiah and judgment on Israel
chaptersContent.content: The people who walked in darkness have seen a great light; those who dwelt in a land of deep darkness, on them has light shone. For to us a child is born, to us a son is given; and the government shall be upon his shoulder, and his name shall be called Wonderful Counselor.

chaptersContent.title: Assyria, God's Instrument
chaptersContent.summary: Assyria as God's tool of judgment and their coming downfall
chaptersContent.content: Woe to Assyria, the rod of my anger; the staff in their hands is my fury! I will send him against a godless nation, and against the people of my wrath I will command him to take spoil and seize plunder. In that day the remnant of Israel and the survivors of the house of Jacob will no more lean on him who struck them.

chaptersContent.title: The Righteous Branch
chaptersContent.summary: Prophecy of the Messiah and the peaceable kingdom
chaptersContent.content: There shall come forth a shoot from the stump of Jesse, and a branch from his roots shall bear fruit. And the Spirit of the Lord shall rest upon him, the Spirit of wisdom and understanding, the Spirit of counsel and might, the Spirit of knowledge and the fear of the Lord.

chaptersContent.title: The Song of Salvation
chaptersContent.summary: Song of praise for God's salvation and comfort
chaptersContent.content: Behold, God is my salvation; I will trust, and will not be afraid; for the Lord God is my strength and my song, and he has become my salvation. With joy you will draw water from the wells of salvation. Shout, and sing for joy, O inhabitant of Zion, for great in your midst is the Holy One of Israel.

chaptersContent.title: Comfort for God's People
chaptersContent.summary: God's comfort and the greatness of His power
chaptersContent.content: Comfort, comfort my people, says your God. A voice cries: 'In the wilderness prepare the way of the Lord; make straight in the desert a highway for our God.' But they who wait for the Lord shall renew their strength; they shall mount up with wings like eagles.

chaptersContent.title: The Suffering Servant
chaptersContent.summary: Prophecy of the Messiah's suffering for our sins
chaptersContent.content: But he was pierced for our transgressions; he was crushed for our iniquities; upon him was the chastisement that brought us peace, and with his wounds we are healed. All we like sheep have gone astray; we have turned every one to his own way.

chaptersContent.title: Come to the Waters
chaptersContent.summary: Invitation to come to God for salvation and life
chaptersContent.content: Come, everyone who thirsts, come to the waters; and he who has no money, come, buy and eat! Come, buy wine and milk without money and without price. Seek the Lord while he may be found; call upon him while he is near.

chaptersContent.title: The Fall of Babylon
chaptersContent.summary: Prophecy of Babylon's destruction and God's judgment
chaptersContent.content: The oracle concerning Babylon which Isaiah the son of Amoz saw. Wail, for the day of the Lord is near; as destruction from the Almighty it will come! And Babylon, the glory of kingdoms, the splendor and pomp of the Chaldeans, will be like Sodom and Gomorrah.

chaptersContent.title: The Fall of the King of Babylon
chaptersContent.summary: Taunt song against the fallen king and restoration of Israel
chaptersContent.content: For the Lord will have compassion on Jacob and will again choose Israel, and will set them in their own land, and sojourners will join them and attach themselves to the house of Jacob. How you are fallen from heaven, O Day Star, son of Dawn!

chaptersContent.title: An Oracle Concerning Moab
chaptersContent.summary: Prophecy of Moab's destruction and lamentation
chaptersContent.content: An oracle concerning Moab. Because Ar of Moab is laid waste in a night, Moab is undone; because Kir of Moab is laid waste in a night, Moab is undone. My heart cries out for Moab; her fugitives flee to Zoar, to Eglath-shelishiyah.

chaptersContent.title: Moab's Plea for Refuge
chaptersContent.summary: Moab's request for help and God's response
chaptersContent.content: Send the lamb to the ruler of the land, from Sela, by way of the desert, to the mount of the daughter of Zion. Then a throne will be established in steadfast love, and on it will sit in faithfulness in the tent of David one who judges and seeks justice.

chaptersContent.title: An Oracle Concerning Damascus
chaptersContent.summary: Prophecy against Damascus and Ephraim
chaptersContent.content: An oracle concerning Damascus. Behold, Damascus will cease to be a city and will become a heap of ruins. In that day man will look to his Maker, and his eyes will look on the Holy One of Israel. For you have forgotten the God of your salvation.

chaptersContent.title: An Oracle Concerning Cush
chaptersContent.summary: Message to Cush about God's plan
chaptersContent.content: Ah, land of whirring wings that is beyond the rivers of Cush, which sends ambassadors by the sea, in vessels of papyrus on the waters! Go, you swift messengers, to a nation tall and smooth, to a people feared near and far.

chaptersContent.title: An Oracle Concerning Egypt
chaptersContent.summary: Prophecy of Egypt's judgment and future blessing
chaptersContent.content: An oracle concerning Egypt. Behold, the Lord is riding on a swift cloud and comes to Egypt; and the idols of Egypt will tremble at his presence, and the heart of the Egyptians will melt within them. In that day there will be an altar to the Lord in the midst of the land of Egypt.

chaptersContent.title: A Sign Against Egypt and Cush
chaptersContent.summary: Isaiah's symbolic act warning against trusting Egypt
chaptersContent.content: In the year that the commander in chief, who was sent by Sargon the king of Assyria, came to Ashdod and fought against it and captured itat that time the Lord spoke by Isaiah the son of Amoz, saying, 'Go, and loose the sackcloth from your waist.'

chaptersContent.title: The Fall of Babylon
chaptersContent.summary: Vision of Babylon's fall and Edom's watchman
chaptersContent.content: The oracle concerning the wilderness of the sea. As whirlwinds in the Negeb sweep on, it comes from the desert, from a terrible land. Behold, here comes a man in a chariot with a couple of horsemen. And he answered, 'Fallen, fallen is Babylon.'

chaptersContent.title: The Valley of Vision
chaptersContent.summary: Prophecy against Jerusalem and Shebna
chaptersContent.content: The oracle concerning the valley of vision. What do you mean that you have gone up, all of you, to the housetops, you who are full of shoutings, tumultuous city, exultant town? In that day the Lord God of hosts called for weeping and mourning.

chaptersContent.title: An Oracle Concerning Tyre
chaptersContent.summary: Prophecy of Tyre's destruction and restoration
chaptersContent.content: The oracle concerning Tyre. Wail, O ships of Tarshish, for Tyre is laid waste, without house or harbor! From the land of Cyprus it is revealed to them. At the end of seventy years, the Lord will visit Tyre, and she will return to her wages and will prostitute herself.

chaptersContent.title: The Earth Laid Waste
chaptersContent.summary: Prophecy of worldwide judgment and the day of the Lord
chaptersContent.content: Behold, the Lord will empty the earth and make it desolate, and he will twist its surface and scatter its inhabitants. They lift up their voices, they sing for joy; over the majesty of the Lord they shout from the west. Then the moon will be confounded.

chaptersContent.title: God Will Swallow Up Death
chaptersContent.summary: Praise for God's salvation and the feast on Mount Zion
chaptersContent.content: O Lord, you are my God; I will exalt you; I will praise your name, for you have done wonderful things, plans formed of old, faithful and sure. He will swallow up death forever; and the Lord God will wipe away tears from all faces.

chaptersContent.title: You Will Keep Him in Perfect Peace
chaptersContent.summary: Song of trust and prayer for God's people
chaptersContent.content: You keep him in perfect peace whose mind is stayed on you, because he trusts in you. Trust in the Lord forever, for the Lord God is an everlasting rock. Your dead shall live; their bodies shall rise. You who dwell in the dust, awake and sing for joy!

chaptersContent.title: The Redemption of Israel
chaptersContent.summary: Prophecy of Israel's restoration and judgment on Leviathan
chaptersContent.content: In that day the Lord with his hard and great and strong sword will punish Leviathan the fleeing serpent, Leviathan the twisting serpent, and he will slay the dragon that is in the sea. In days to come Jacob shall take root, Israel shall blossom and put forth shoots.

chaptersContent.title: Judgment on Ephraim and Jerusalem
chaptersContent.summary: Warning against pride and the cornerstone of Zion
chaptersContent.content: Ah, the proud crown of the drunkards of Ephraim, and the fading flower of its glorious beauty, which is on the head of the rich valley of those overcome with wine! Therefore thus says the Lord God, Behold, I am the one who has laid as a foundation in Zion.

chaptersContent.title: The Siege of Jerusalem
chaptersContent.summary: Prophecy of Jerusalem's siege and spiritual blindness
chaptersContent.content: Ah, Ariel, Ariel, the city where David encamped! Add year to year; let the feasts run their round. And the Lord said: Because this people draw near with their mouth and honor me with their lips, while their hearts are far from me.

chaptersContent.title: Do Not Go Down to Egypt
chaptersContent.summary: Warning against trusting Egypt and promise of restoration
chaptersContent.content: Ah, stubborn children, declares the Lord, who carry out a plan, but not mine, and who make an alliance, but not of my Spirit, that they may add sin to sin. For thus said the Lord God, the Holy One of Israel, In returning and rest you shall be saved.

chaptersContent.title: Woe to Those Who Go Down to Egypt
chaptersContent.summary: Warning against trusting in horses and chariots
chaptersContent.content: Woe to those who go down to Egypt for help and rely on horses, who trust in chariots because they are many and in horsemen because they are very strong, but do not look to the Holy One of Israel or consult the Lord! The Egyptians are man, and not God.

chaptersContent.title: A King Will Reign in Righteousness
chaptersContent.summary: Prophecy of the righteous king and the Spirit's outpouring
chaptersContent.content: Behold, a king will reign in righteousness, and princes will rule in justice. Until the Spirit is poured upon us from on high, and the wilderness becomes a fruitful field, and the fruitful field is deemed a forest. And the effect of righteousness will be peace.

chaptersContent.title: O Lord, Be Gracious to Us
chaptersContent.summary: Prayer for God's help and vision of the future kingdom
chaptersContent.content: O Lord, be gracious to us; we wait for you. Be our arm every morning, our salvation in the time of trouble. And he will be the stability of your times, abundance of salvation, wisdom and knowledge; the fear of the Lord is Zion's treasure.

chaptersContent.title: Judgment on the Nations
chaptersContent.summary: Prophecy of God's wrath against all nations
chaptersContent.content: Draw near, O nations, to hear, and give attention, O peoples! Let the earth hear, and all that fills it; the world, and all that comes from it. For the Lord is enraged against all the nations, and furious against all their hosts.

chaptersContent.title: The Ransomed Shall Return
chaptersContent.summary: Prophecy of the wilderness blossoming and the way of holiness
chaptersContent.content: The wilderness and the dry land shall be glad; the desert shall rejoice and blossom like the crocus; it shall blossom abundantly and rejoice with joy and singing. And a highway shall be there, and it shall be called the Way of Holiness.

chaptersContent.title: Sennacherib Invades Judah
chaptersContent.summary: Historical account of Assyrian invasion and threats
chaptersContent.content: In the fourteenth year of King Hezekiah, Sennacherib king of Assyria came up against all the fortified cities of Judah and took them. And the king of Assyria sent the Rabshakeh from Lachish to King Hezekiah at Jerusalem, with a great army.

chaptersContent.title: Hezekiah's Prayer and God's Answer
chaptersContent.summary: Hezekiah's prayer and God's deliverance from Assyria
chaptersContent.content: As soon as King Hezekiah heard it, he tore his clothes and covered himself with sackcloth and went into the house of the Lord. And Hezekiah prayed to the Lord: O Lord of hosts, God of Israel, enthroned above the cherubim, you are the God.

chaptersContent.title: Hezekiah's Illness and Recovery
chaptersContent.summary: Hezekiah's sickness, prayer, and God's healing
chaptersContent.content: In those days Hezekiah became sick and was at the point of death. And Isaiah the prophet the son of Amoz came to him, and said to him, Thus says the Lord: Set your house in order, for you shall die, you shall not recover.

chaptersContent.title: Envoys from Babylon
chaptersContent.summary: Hezekiah shows treasures to Babylonian envoys
chaptersContent.content: At that time Merodach-baladan the son of Baladan, king of Babylon, sent envoys with letters and a present to Hezekiah, for he heard that he had been sick and had recovered. And Hezekiah was pleased with them, and showed them his treasure house.

chaptersContent.title: Fear Not, for I Am with You
chaptersContent.summary: God's comfort to Israel and challenge to idols
chaptersContent.content: Listen to me in silence, O coastlands; let the peoples renew their strength; let them approach, then let them speak; let us together draw near for judgment. Fear not, for I am with you; be not dismayed, for I am your God.

chaptersContent.title: The Servant of the Lord
chaptersContent.summary: Description of the Lord's Servant and His mission
chaptersContent.content: Behold my servant, whom I uphold, my chosen, in whom my soul delights; I have put my Spirit upon him; he will bring forth justice to the nations. I am the Lord; that is my name; my glory I give to no other.

chaptersContent.title: Israel's Only Savior
chaptersContent.summary: God's promise to redeem Israel and be their Savior
chaptersContent.content: But now thus says the Lord, he who created you, O Jacob, he who formed you, O Israel: Fear not, for I have redeemed you; I have called you by name, you are mine. I, I am the Lord, and besides me there is no savior.

chaptersContent.title: Israel the Lord's Chosen
chaptersContent.summary: God's choice of Israel and condemnation of idolatry
chaptersContent.content: But now hear, O Jacob my servant, Israel whom I have chosen! Thus says the Lord who made you, who formed you from the womb and will help you: Fear not, O Jacob my servant, Jeshurun whom I have chosen. I have blotted out your transgressions like a cloud.

chaptersContent.title: Cyrus, God's Anointed
chaptersContent.summary: God's use of Cyrus and His sovereignty over all
chaptersContent.content: Thus says the Lord to his anointed, to Cyrus, whose right hand I have grasped, to subdue nations before him and to loose the belts of kings, to open doors before him that gates may not be closed. I am the Lord, and there is no other.

chaptersContent.title: The Idols of Babylon
chaptersContent.summary: Contrast between idols and the living God
chaptersContent.content: Bel bows down; Nebo stoops; their idols are on beasts and livestock; these things you carry are borne as burdens on weary beasts. Even to your old age I am he, and to gray hairs I will carry you. I have made, and I will bear; I will carry and will save.

chaptersContent.title: The Fall of Babylon
chaptersContent.summary: Prophecy of Babylon's destruction and humiliation
chaptersContent.content: Come down and sit in the dust, O virgin daughter of Babylon; sit on the ground without a throne, O daughter of the Chaldeans! For you shall no more be called tender and delicate. I was angry with my people; I profaned my heritage.

chaptersContent.title: Israel's Obstinacy
chaptersContent.summary: God's rebuke of Israel's stubbornness and His faithfulness
chaptersContent.content: Hear this, O house of Jacob, who are called by the name of Israel, and who came from the waters of Judah, who swear by the name of the Lord and confess the God of Israel, but not in truth or right. For my name's sake I defer my anger.

chaptersContent.title: The Servant of the Lord
chaptersContent.summary: The Servant's mission to restore Israel and be a light to nations
chaptersContent.content: Listen to me, O coastlands, and give attention, you peoples from afar. The Lord called me from the womb, from the body of my mother he named my name. I will make you as a light for the nations, that my salvation may reach to the end of the earth.

chaptersContent.title: Israel's Sin and the Servant's Obedience
chaptersContent.summary: Israel's rebellion contrasted with the Servant's submission
chaptersContent.content: Thus says the Lord: Where is your mother's certificate of divorce, with which I sent her away? Or which of my creditors is it to whom I have sold you? Behold, you were sold for your iniquities, and for your transgressions your mother was sent away.

chaptersContent.title: Listen to Me, You Who Pursue Righteousness
chaptersContent.summary: God's comfort to those who seek righteousness
chaptersContent.content: Listen to me, you who pursue righteousness, you who seek the Lord: look to the rock from which you were hewn, and to the quarry from which you were dug. Listen to me, you who know righteousness, the people in whose heart is my law.

chaptersContent.title: The Lord's Coming Salvation
chaptersContent.summary: Prophecy of God's salvation and the beautiful feet of the messenger
chaptersContent.content: Awake, awake, put on your strength, O Zion; put on your beautiful garments, O Jerusalem, the holy city; for there shall no more come into you the uncircumcised and the unclean. How beautiful upon the mountains are the feet of him who brings good news.

chaptersContent.title: The Eternal Covenant of Peace
chaptersContent.summary: Prophecy of Israel's restoration and everlasting peace
chaptersContent.content: Sing, O barren one, who did not bear; break forth into singing and cry aloud, you who have not been in labor! For the children of the desolate one will be more than the children of her who is married, says the Lord. For the mountains may depart.

chaptersContent.title: Salvation for Foreigners
chaptersContent.summary: Promise of salvation for foreigners and eunuchs
chaptersContent.content: Thus says the Lord: Keep justice, and do righteousness, for soon my salvation will come, and my righteousness be revealed. Let not the foreigner who has joined himself to the Lord say, The Lord will surely separate me from his people.

chaptersContent.title: Israel's Futile Idolatry
chaptersContent.summary: Condemnation of Israel's idolatry and promise of healing
chaptersContent.content: The righteous man perishes, and no one lays it to heart; devout men are taken away, while no one understands. For the righteous man is taken away from calamity, he enters into peace; they rest in their beds who walk in their uprightness.

chaptersContent.title: True and False Fasting
chaptersContent.summary: God's requirements for acceptable fasting and worship
chaptersContent.content: Cry aloud; do not hold back; lift up your voice like a trumpet; declare to my people their transgression, to the house of Jacob their sins. Is not this the fast that I choose: to loose the bonds of wickedness, to undo the straps of the yoke.

chaptersContent.title: Evil and Oppression
chaptersContent.summary: Israel's sins and God's promise of redemption
chaptersContent.content: Behold, the Lord's hand is not shortened, that it cannot save, or his ear dull, that it cannot hear; but your iniquities have made a separation between you and your God, and your sins have hidden his face from you so that he does not hear.

chaptersContent.title: The Future Glory of Israel
chaptersContent.summary: Prophecy of Israel's future glory and the nations' tribute
chaptersContent.content: Arise, shine, for your light has come, and the glory of the Lord has risen upon you. For behold, darkness shall cover the earth, and thick darkness the peoples; but the Lord will arise upon you, and his glory will be seen upon you.

chaptersContent.title: Zion's Coming Salvation
chaptersContent.summary: Promise of Zion's restoration and new names
chaptersContent.content: For Zion's sake I will not keep silent, and for Jerusalem's sake I will not be quiet, until her righteousness goes forth as brightness, and her salvation as a burning torch. You shall no more be termed Forsaken, and your land shall no more be termed Desolate.

chaptersContent.title: The Lord's Day of Vengeance
chaptersContent.summary: God's judgment on Edom and His mercy to Israel
chaptersContent.content: Who is this who comes from Edom, in crimsoned garments from Bozrah, he who is splendid in his apparel, marching in the greatness of his strength? It is I, speaking in righteousness, mighty to save. In all their affliction he was afflicted.

chaptersContent.title: Prayer for Mercy and Help
chaptersContent.summary: Prayer for God's intervention and restoration
chaptersContent.content: Oh that you would rend the heavens and come down, that the mountains might quake at your presenceas when fire kindles brushwood and the fire causes water to boilto make your name known to your adversaries, and that the nations might tremble at your presence!

chaptersContent.title: New Heavens and New Earth
chaptersContent.summary: God's judgment on sinners and promise of new creation
chaptersContent.content: I was ready to be sought by those who did not ask for me; I was ready to be found by those who did not seek me. I said, Here I am, here I am, to a nation that was not called by my name. For behold, I create new heavens and a new earth.

chaptersContent.title: Final Judgment and New Heavens
chaptersContent.summary: Final judgment on sinners and the new heavens and earth
chaptersContent.content: Thus says the Lord: Heaven is my throne, and the earth is my footstool; what is the house that you would build for me, and what is the place of my rest? For as the new heavens and the new earth that I make shall remain before me.

chaptersContent.title: The Year of the Lord's Favor
chaptersContent.summary: Prophecy of the Messiah's ministry and restoration
chaptersContent.content: The Spirit of the Lord God is upon me, because the Lord has anointed me to bring good news to the poor; he has sent me to bind up the brokenhearted, to proclaim liberty to the captives, and the opening of the prison to those who are bound.

books.name: Jeremiah
books.description: The weeping prophet's call to repentance and prophecies of judgment
books.author: Jeremiah

chaptersContent.title: Jeremiah's Call
chaptersContent.summary: God calls Jeremiah to be a prophet to the nations
chaptersContent.content: Before I formed you in the womb I knew you, and before you were born I consecrated you; I appointed you a prophet to the nations. Then the Lord put out his hand and touched my mouth. And the Lord said to me, 'Behold, I have put my words in your mouth.'

chaptersContent.title: Israel's Unfaithfulness
chaptersContent.summary: God accuses Israel of forsaking Him for worthless idols
chaptersContent.content: Go and proclaim in the hearing of Jerusalem, Thus says the Lord: I remember the devotion of your youth, your love as a bride, how you followed me in the wilderness, in a land not sown. For my people have committed two evils: they have forsaken me, the fountain of living waters, and hewed out cisterns for themselves, broken cisterns that can hold no water.

chaptersContent.title: Call to Repentance
chaptersContent.summary: God calls unfaithful Israel to return to Him
chaptersContent.content: Go, and proclaim these words toward the north, and say, Return, faithless Israel, declares the Lord. I will not look on you in anger, for I am merciful, declares the Lord; I will not be angry forever. Return, O faithless sons; I will heal your faithlessness.

chaptersContent.title: Judah Threatened with Invasion
chaptersContent.summary: Warning of invasion from the north and call to repentance
chaptersContent.content: If you return, O Israel, declares the Lord, to me you should return. If you remove your detestable things from my presence, and do not waver, and if you swear, As the Lord lives, in truth, in justice, and in righteousness, then nations shall bless themselves in him.

chaptersContent.title: Judgment on Jerusalem
chaptersContent.summary: God's judgment on Jerusalem for their sins
chaptersContent.content: Run to and fro through the streets of Jerusalem, look and take note! Search her squares to see if you can find a man, one who does justice and seeks truth, that I may pardon her. O Lord, do not your eyes look for truth? You have struck them down, but they felt no anguish.

chaptersContent.title: The Siege of Jerusalem
chaptersContent.summary: Warning of the coming siege and destruction of Jerusalem
chaptersContent.content: They have healed the wound of my people lightly, saying, Peace, peace, when there is no peace. Thus says the Lord: Stand by the roads, and look, and ask for the ancient paths, where the good way is; and walk in it, and find rest for your souls. But they said, We will not walk in it.

chaptersContent.title: The Temple Sermon
chaptersContent.summary: Jeremiah preaches against false trust in the temple
chaptersContent.content: Do not trust in these deceptive words: This is the temple of the Lord, the temple of the Lord, the temple of the Lord. Has this house, which is called by my name, become a den of robbers in your eyes? Behold, I myself have seen it, declares the Lord.

chaptersContent.title: The People's Refusal to Repent
chaptersContent.summary: The people refuse to repent despite their suffering
chaptersContent.content: You shall say to them, Thus says the Lord: When men fall, do they not rise again? When one turns away, does he not return? Even the stork in the heavens knows her times, and the turtledove, swallow, and crane keep the time of their coming, but my people know not the rules of the Lord.

chaptersContent.title: Lament for the People
chaptersContent.summary: Jeremiah laments the destruction and corruption of his people
chaptersContent.content: Oh that my head were waters, and my eyes a fountain of tears, that I might weep day and night for the slain of the daughter of my people! Thus says the Lord: Let not the wise man boast in his wisdom, let not the mighty man boast in his might, let not the rich man boast in his riches.

chaptersContent.title: Idols Are Worthless
chaptersContent.summary: Contrast between worthless idols and the living God
chaptersContent.content: There is none like you, O Lord; you are great, and your name is great in might. But the Lord is the true God; he is the living God and the everlasting King. At his wrath the earth quakes, and the nations cannot endure his indignation.

chaptersContent.title: The Covenant Curse
chaptersContent.summary: Warning about the consequences of breaking the covenant
chaptersContent.content: Cursed be the man who does not hear the words of this covenant that I commanded your fathers when I brought them out of the land of Egypt, from the iron furnace, saying, Listen to my voice. But they did not obey or incline their ear, but everyone walked in the stubbornness of his evil heart.

chaptersContent.title: Jeremiah's Complaint
chaptersContent.summary: Jeremiah questions why the wicked prosper
chaptersContent.content: Righteous are you, O Lord, when I complain to you; yet I would plead my case before you. Why does the way of the wicked prosper? Why do all who are treacherous thrive? If you have raced with men on foot, and they have wearied you, how will you compete with horses?

chaptersContent.title: The Linen Loincloth
chaptersContent.summary: Parable of the ruined loincloth showing Judah's corruption
chaptersContent.content: For as the loincloth clings to the waist of a man, so I made the whole house of Israel and the whole house of Judah cling to me, declares the Lord, that they might be for me a people, a name, a praise, and a glory, but they would not listen.

chaptersContent.title: Drought and Famine
chaptersContent.summary: Judah suffers drought and Jeremiah's intercession
chaptersContent.content: Though our iniquities testify against us, act, O Lord, for your name's sake; for our backslidings are many; we have sinned against you. Why should you be like a man confused, like a mighty warrior who cannot save? Yet you, O Lord, are in the midst of us, and we are called by your name; do not leave us.

chaptersContent.title: God's Rejection of Judah
chaptersContent.summary: God rejects Judah despite Jeremiah's intercession
chaptersContent.content: Then the Lord said to me, Though Moses and Samuel stood before me, yet my heart would not turn toward this people. Send them out of my sight, and let them go! Therefore thus says the Lord: If you return, I will restore you, and you shall stand before me.

chaptersContent.title: Jeremiah Forbidden to Marry
chaptersContent.summary: God forbids Jeremiah to marry as a sign of coming judgment
chaptersContent.content: You shall not take a wife, nor shall you have sons or daughters in this place. For thus says the Lord concerning the sons and daughters who are born in this place, and concerning the mothers who bore them and the fathers who fathered them in this land.

chaptersContent.title: The Sin of Judah
chaptersContent.summary: Judah's sin is engraved with an iron pen
chaptersContent.content: The sin of Judah is written with a pen of iron; with a point of diamond it is engraved on the tablet of their heart, and on the horns of their altars. Cursed is the man who trusts in man and makes flesh his strength, whose heart turns away from the Lord.

chaptersContent.title: The Potter and the Clay
chaptersContent.summary: God's sovereignty illustrated through the potter and clay
chaptersContent.content: So I went down to the potter's house, and there he was working at his wheel. And the vessel he was making of clay was spoiled in the potter's hand, and he reworked it into another vessel, as it seemed good to the potter to do. O house of Israel, can I not do with you as this potter has done? declares the Lord. Behold, like the clay in the potter's hand, so are you in my hand, O house of Israel.

chaptersContent.title: The Broken Jar
chaptersContent.summary: Jeremiah breaks a jar as a sign of coming destruction
chaptersContent.content: Thus says the Lord, Go, buy a potter's earthenware flask, and take some of the elders of the people and some of the senior priests. Then you shall break the flask in the sight of the men who go with you, and shall say to them, Thus says the Lord of hosts: So will I break this people and this city.

chaptersContent.title: Jeremiah's Complaint
chaptersContent.summary: Jeremiah complains about his prophetic ministry
chaptersContent.content: O Lord, you have deceived me, and I was deceived; you are stronger than I, and you have prevailed. I have become a laughingstock all the day; everyone mocks me. If I say, I will not mention him, or speak any more in his name, there is in my heart as it were a burning fire shut up in my bones.

chaptersContent.title: Zedekiah's Request
chaptersContent.summary: King Zedekiah asks Jeremiah to inquire of the Lord
chaptersContent.content: Inquire of the Lord for us, for Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon is making war against us. Perhaps the Lord will deal with us according to all his wonderful deeds and will make him withdraw from us. Behold, I set before you the way of life and the way of death.

chaptersContent.title: Judgment on the Kings
chaptersContent.summary: Judgment on the kings of Judah for their wickedness
chaptersContent.content: Thus says the Lord: Do justice and righteousness, and deliver from the hand of the oppressor him who has been robbed. And do no wrong or violence to the resident alien, the fatherless, and the widow, nor shed innocent blood in this place.

chaptersContent.title: The Righteous Branch
chaptersContent.summary: Promise of the righteous Branch and judgment on false prophets
chaptersContent.content: Behold, the days are coming, declares the Lord, when I will raise up for David a righteous Branch, and he shall reign as king and deal wisely, and shall execute justice and righteousness in the land. Is not my word like fire, declares the Lord, and like a hammer that breaks the rock in pieces?

chaptersContent.title: The Good and Bad Figs
chaptersContent.summary: Vision of good and bad figs representing exiles and those left behind
chaptersContent.content: Thus says the Lord, the God of Israel: Like these good figs, so I will regard as good the exiles from Judah, whom I have sent away from this place to the land of the Chaldeans. I will set my eyes on them for good, and I will bring them back to this land.

chaptersContent.title: Seventy Years of Captivity
chaptersContent.summary: Prophecy of seventy years of Babylonian captivity
chaptersContent.content: Behold, I will send for all the tribes of the north, declares the Lord, and for Nebuchadnezzar the king of Babylon, my servant, and I will bring them against this land and its inhabitants, and against all these surrounding nations. This whole land shall become a ruin and a waste, and these nations shall serve the king of Babylon seventy years.

chaptersContent.title: Jeremiah Threatened with Death
chaptersContent.summary: Jeremiah is threatened with death for his prophecies
chaptersContent.content: Thus says the Lord: Stand in the court of the Lord's house, and speak to all the cities of Judah that come to worship in the house of the Lord all the words that I command you to speak to them; do not hold back a word. And when Jeremiah had finished speaking all that the Lord had commanded him to speak to all the people.

chaptersContent.title: The Yoke of Babylon
chaptersContent.summary: Jeremiah wears a yoke to symbolize submission to Babylon
chaptersContent.content: Now I have given all these lands into the hand of Nebuchadnezzar, the king of Babylon, my servant, and I have given him also the beasts of the field to serve him. But if any nation or kingdom will not serve this Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon, and put its neck under the yoke of the king of Babylon.

chaptersContent.title: Hananiah's False Prophecy
chaptersContent.summary: Hananiah falsely prophesies the end of Babylonian rule
chaptersContent.content: Thus says the Lord of hosts, the God of Israel: I have broken the yoke of the king of Babylon. Within two years I will bring back to this place all the vessels of the Lord's house, which Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon took away from this place and carried to Babylon.

chaptersContent.title: Letter to the Exiles
chaptersContent.summary: Jeremiah's letter of hope to the Babylonian exiles
chaptersContent.content: For I know the plans I have for you, declares the Lord, plans for welfare and not for evil, to give you a future and a hope. Then you will call upon me and come and pray to me, and I will hear you. You will seek me and find me, when you seek me with all your heart.

chaptersContent.title: Restoration Promised
chaptersContent.summary: Promise of restoration and the return of the exiles
chaptersContent.content: For behold, days are coming, declares the Lord, when I will restore the fortunes of my people, Israel and Judah, says the Lord, and I will bring them back to the land that I gave to their fathers, and they shall take possession of it. Fear not, O Jacob my servant, declares the Lord, nor be dismayed, O Israel.

chaptersContent.title: The New Covenant
chaptersContent.summary: God promises a new covenant written on hearts
chaptersContent.content: Behold, the days are coming, declares the Lord, when I will make a new covenant with the house of Israel and the house of Judah. But this is the covenant that I will make with the house of Israel after those days, declares the Lord: I will put my law within them, and I will write it on their hearts. And I will be their God, and they shall be my people.

chaptersContent.title: Jeremiah Buys a Field
chaptersContent.summary: Jeremiah buys a field as a sign of future restoration
chaptersContent.content: For thus says the Lord of hosts, the God of Israel: Houses and fields and vineyards shall again be bought in this land. Ah, Lord God! It is you who have made the heavens and the earth by your great power and by your outstretched arm! Nothing is too hard for you.

chaptersContent.title: Restoration Promised Again
chaptersContent.summary: Further promises of restoration and the Davidic covenant
chaptersContent.content: Call to me and I will answer you, and will tell you great and hidden things that you have not known. Behold, I will bring to it health and healing, and I will heal them and reveal to them abundance of prosperity and security.

chaptersContent.title: The Covenant of Freedom
chaptersContent.summary: Judah breaks the covenant to free Hebrew slaves
chaptersContent.content: You recently repented and did what was right in my eyes by proclaiming liberty, each to his neighbor, and you made a covenant before me in the house that is called by my name. But then you turned around and profaned my name when each of you took back his male and female slaves.

chaptersContent.title: The Rechabites
chaptersContent.summary: The Rechabites' obedience contrasted with Judah's disobedience
chaptersContent.content: But they said, We will drink no wine, for Jonadab the son of Rechab, our father, commanded us, You shall not drink wine, neither you nor your sons, forever. The command that Jonadab the son of Rechab gave to his sons, that they should not drink wine, has been kept.

chaptersContent.title: The Scroll Read to the King
chaptersContent.summary: Jeremiah's scroll is read to King Jehoiakim who burns it
chaptersContent.content: Take a scroll and write on it all the words that I have spoken to you against Israel and Judah and all the nations, from the day I spoke to you, from the days of Josiah until today. And when Jehudi had read three or four columns, the king would cut them off with a knife.

chaptersContent.title: Jeremiah Imprisoned
chaptersContent.summary: Jeremiah is imprisoned during the siege of Jerusalem
chaptersContent.content: King Zedekiah sent Jehucal the son of Shelemiah, and Zephaniah the priest, the son of Maaseiah, to say to Jeremiah the prophet, Please pray for us to the Lord our God. Then King Zedekiah sent for him and received him. The king questioned him secretly in his house.

chaptersContent.title: Jeremiah in the Cistern
chaptersContent.summary: Jeremiah is thrown into a cistern but rescued by Ebed-melech
chaptersContent.content: So they took Jeremiah and cast him into the cistern of Malchiah, the king's son, which was in the court of the guard, letting Jeremiah down by ropes. And there was no water in the cistern, but only mud, and Jeremiah sank in the mud.

chaptersContent.title: Jerusalem Falls
chaptersContent.summary: Jerusalem falls to Babylon and Jeremiah is freed
chaptersContent.content: In the eleventh year of Zedekiah, in the fourth month, on the ninth day of the month, a breach was made in the city. Then all the officials of the king of Babylon came and sat in the middle gate: Nergal-sar-ezer of Samgar, Nebu-sar-sekim the Rab-saris.

chaptersContent.title: Jeremiah Remains in Judah
chaptersContent.summary: Jeremiah chooses to remain in Judah with Gedaliah
chaptersContent.content: The captain of the guard took Jeremiah and said to him, The Lord your God pronounced this disaster against this place. The Lord has brought it about, and has done as he said. Because you sinned against the Lord and did not obey his voice, this thing has come upon you.

chaptersContent.title: Gedaliah Murdered
chaptersContent.summary: Gedaliah is murdered and more people flee to Egypt
chaptersContent.content: Ishmael the son of Nethaniah and the ten men with him rose up and struck down Gedaliah the son of Ahikam, son of Shaphan, with the sword, and killed him, whom the king of Babylon had appointed governor over the land.

chaptersContent.title: Flight to Egypt
chaptersContent.summary: The people ask Jeremiah about going to Egypt
chaptersContent.content: Pray for us to the Lord our God, for all this remnant (for we are left with but a few, as you can see), that the Lord your God may show us the way we should go, and the thing that we should do. Whether it is good or bad, we will obey the voice of the Lord our God.

chaptersContent.title: Jeremiah Taken to Egypt
chaptersContent.summary: The people take Jeremiah to Egypt despite God's warning
chaptersContent.content: Azariah the son of Hoshaiah and Johanan the son of Kareah and all the insolent men said to Jeremiah, You are telling a lie. The Lord our God did not send you to say, Do not go to Egypt to live there. But Johanan the son of Kareah and all the commanders of the forces took all the remnant of Judah.

chaptersContent.title: Judgment on Egypt
chaptersContent.summary: God's judgment on the Jews who went to Egypt
chaptersContent.content: And now thus says the Lord God of hosts, the God of Israel: Why do you commit this great evil against yourselves, to cut off from you man and woman, infant and child, from the midst of Judah, leaving you no remnant?

chaptersContent.title: Message to Baruch
chaptersContent.summary: God's message to Jeremiah's scribe Baruch
chaptersContent.content: You said, Woe is me! For the Lord has added sorrow to my pain. I am weary with my groaning, and I find no rest. Thus you shall say to him, Thus says the Lord: Behold, what I have built I am breaking down, and what I have planted I am plucking up.

chaptersContent.title: Judgment on Egypt
chaptersContent.summary: Prophecy of Egypt's defeat by Babylon
chaptersContent.content: That day belongs to the Lord God of hosts, a day of vengeance, to avenge himself on his foes. The sword shall devour and be sated and drink its fill of their blood. For the Lord God of hosts holds a sacrifice in the north country by the river Euphrates.

chaptersContent.title: Judgment on the Philistines
chaptersContent.summary: Prophecy of Philistine destruction by Babylon
chaptersContent.content: The word of the Lord that came to Jeremiah the prophet concerning the Philistines, before Pharaoh struck down Gaza. For the Lord is destroying the Philistines, the remnant of the coastland of Caphtor. Woe to you, O sword of the Lord! How long till you are quiet?

chaptersContent.title: Judgment on Moab
chaptersContent.summary: Prophecy of Moab's destruction and captivity
chaptersContent.content: Moab has been at ease from his youth and has settled on his dregs; he has not been emptied from vessel to vessel, nor has he gone into exile; so his taste remains in him, and his scent is not changed. We have heard of the pride of Moabhe is very proudof his loftiness, his pride, and his arrogance.

chaptersContent.title: Judgment on Ammon and Others
chaptersContent.summary: Judgment on Ammon, Edom, Damascus, and other nations
chaptersContent.content: Therefore, behold, the days are coming, declares the Lord, when I will cause the battle cry to be heard against Rabbah of the Ammonites; it shall become a desolate mound, and its villages shall be burned with fire; then Israel shall dispossess those who dispossessed him.

chaptersContent.title: Judgment on Babylon
chaptersContent.summary: Prophecy of Babylon's fall and Israel's restoration
chaptersContent.content: Declare among the nations and proclaim, set up a banner and proclaim, conceal it not, and say: Babylon is taken, Bel is put to shame, Merodach is dismayed. Her images are put to shame, her idols are dismayed. Flee from the midst of Babylon, and go out of the land of the Chaldeans.

chaptersContent.title: Babylon's Complete Destruction
chaptersContent.summary: Detailed prophecy of Babylon's complete destruction
chaptersContent.content: Flee from the midst of Babylon, and let each one save his life! Be not cut off in her punishment, for this is the time of the Lord's vengeance, the repayment he is rendering her. We would have healed Babylon, but she was not to be healed.

chaptersContent.title: The Fall of Jerusalem
chaptersContent.summary: Historical account of Jerusalem's fall and exile
chaptersContent.content: For because of the anger of the Lord it came to the point in Jerusalem and Judah that he cast them out from his presence. And Zedekiah rebelled against the king of Babylon. Then he put out the eyes of Zedekiah, and bound him in chains.

books.name: Lamentations
books.description: Mourning poems over Jerusalem's destruction
books.author: Jeremiah

chaptersContent.title: Jerusalem's Desolation
chaptersContent.summary: The once-great city of Jerusalem lies in ruins
chaptersContent.content: How lonely sits the city that was full of people! How like a widow has she become, she who was great among the nations! She who was a princess among the provinces has become a slave. Is it nothing to you, all you who pass by? Look and see if there is any sorrow like my sorrow, which was brought upon me.

chaptersContent.title: God's Anger Against Sin
chaptersContent.summary: The Lord's righteous anger against Jerusalem's sins brings destruction
chaptersContent.content: How the Lord in his anger has set the daughter of Zion under a cloud! He has cast down from heaven to earth the splendor of Israel; he has not remembered his footstool in the day of his anger. What can I say for you, to what compare you, O daughter of Jerusalem? What can I liken to you, that I may comfort you, O virgin daughter of Zion? For your ruin is vast as the sea; who can restore you? The Lord has done what he purposed; he has carried out his word, which he commanded long ago; he has thrown down without pity.

chaptersContent.title: Hope in God's Mercy
chaptersContent.summary: Despite suffering, hope remains in God's steadfast love
chaptersContent.content: The steadfast love of the Lord never ceases; his mercies never come to an end; they are new every morning; great is your faithfulness. The Lord is good to those who wait for him, to the soul who seeks him.

chaptersContent.title: The Punishment of Jerusalem
chaptersContent.summary: The terrible consequences of sin and the degradation of the holy city
chaptersContent.content: How the gold has grown dim, how the pure gold is changed! The holy stones lie scattered at the head of every street. The precious sons of Zion, worth their weight in fine gold, how they are regarded as earthen pots, the work of a potter's hands! The Lord gave full vent to his wrath; he poured out his hot anger, and he kindled a fire in Zion that consumed its foundations. The punishment of your iniquity, O daughter of Zion, is accomplished; he will keep you in exile no longer.

chaptersContent.title: A Prayer for Restoration
chaptersContent.summary: A final plea for God to remember and restore His people
chaptersContent.content: Remember, O Lord, what has befallen us; look, and see our disgrace! But you, O Lord, reign forever; your throne endures to all generations. Restore us to yourself, O Lord, that we may be restored! Renew our days as of old.

books.name: Ezekiel
books.description: Visions of God's glory and prophecies of restoration
books.author: Ezekiel

chaptersContent.title: Vision of God's Glory
chaptersContent.summary: Ezekiel sees the glory of God with living creatures and wheels
chaptersContent.content: As I looked, behold, a stormy wind came out of the north, and a great cloud, with brightness around it, and fire flashing forth continually, and in the midst of the fire, as it were gleaming metal. And above the expanse over their heads there was the likeness of a throne, in appearance like sapphire; and seated above the likeness of a throne was a likeness with a human appearance.

chaptersContent.title: Ezekiel's Commission
chaptersContent.summary: God commissions Ezekiel to speak to rebellious Israel
chaptersContent.content: And he said to me, Son of man, I send you to the people of Israel, to nations of rebels, who have rebelled against me. They and their fathers have transgressed against me to this very day. And you shall speak my words to them, whether they hear or refuse to hear, for they are a rebellious house.

chaptersContent.title: Ezekiel's Call
chaptersContent.summary: Ezekiel is called to be a watchman for Israel
chaptersContent.content: Moreover, he said to me, Son of man, all my words that I shall speak to you receive in your heart, and hear with your ears. Son of man, I have made you a watchman for the house of Israel. Whenever you hear a word from my mouth, you shall give them warning from me.

chaptersContent.title: The Siege of Jerusalem
chaptersContent.summary: Ezekiel acts out the siege of Jerusalem
chaptersContent.content: And you, son of man, take a brick and lay it before you, and engrave on it a city, even Jerusalem. And put siegeworks against it, and build a siege wall against it, and cast up a mound against it. Set camps also against it, and plant battering rams against it all around.

chaptersContent.title: Jerusalem's Punishment
chaptersContent.summary: Ezekiel cuts his hair to symbolize Jerusalem's punishment
chaptersContent.content: Thus says the Lord God: This is Jerusalem. I have set her in the center of the nations, with countries all around her. Therefore thus says the Lord God: Because you are more turbulent than the nations that are all around you, and have not walked in my statutes or obeyed my rules.

chaptersContent.title: Judgment on the Mountains
chaptersContent.summary: Judgment on the high places and idols of Israel
chaptersContent.content: And say, You mountains of Israel, hear the word of the Lord God! Thus says the Lord God to the mountains and the hills, to the ravines and the valleys: Behold, I, even I, will bring a sword upon you, and I will destroy your high places.

chaptersContent.title: The End Has Come
chaptersContent.summary: Prophecy that the end has come for Israel
